title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [13, 20, or 27? march 1868]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [13, 20, or 27? March 1868]
text: 13 March 68fridayFriday afternoonDear Walti have just got your letter with 2 doldollars and the paper i have not read it yet but shall this afternoon i had to write to tell you what i had done i couldentcouldn't feel contented till i did well i haventhaven't committed any crime but i have spent the money order you sent me for something i have always wanted but never was able to get well i have got a lounge it was quite cheap and good hair cloth but after i got it i thought i hadenthadn't ought to spent the money but now i have told you i shall feel better but i have got a little money left besides the 2 dolrsdollars you sent me to day i thought i would be saving and george was gone so i would get it so walt i can get along if you send me about 2 dollars next weeki am glad you are going to have new clothsclothes i dont see how you doodo to make your clothsclothes last so long georg is getting somethings every month) i gessguess this is the last peice of furniture i shall get i always wanted a lounge now i have got one i had a letter from Jeff i beleevebelieve i told you Davis was here tuesdayTuesday evening and he and Baynton his partner in Jersey is to come here this afternoon that is the cause of my not reading the paperi have been baking some bread and cake as davis goes away to night so i thought he would probably stay to tea i seem to have quite a number call to see me among the number was Ellen vanwyckEllen Van Wycke she says she liked you and would like to see you she is quite out of health she stayed and had a cup of tea) ann vanwykAnn Van Wycke sister Ester i dontdon't think you ever saw her she married a man by the name of J baylis he had a farm when they were married but drinked and sported it all away and they now live here in great poverty he has been in the hospitallhospital he got drunk and was took to the station house and he tryedtried to cut his throat but didentdidn't succeedJohn vanwyVan Wyck helps her i beleevebelieve but so it is every one has their troubles) you go i see walt to mrs Borroughs yet how does mrs OconorO'Connor and she get along mrs OconorO'Connor thought they would not perhaps i told her she must doo like mrs blackBlack when the woman up stairs said she wouldenwouldn't live with children mrs black told her they would get along nicely)george and i was talking about if the impeachment was carried if it would make any change with you we thought speedSpeed would be the one that would take the place of stansburyStanbery) doodo you know walt i have always felt a kind of sadness when i read the articles of impeacimpeachment not but what i always thought he was bad but there is so many things to be considered) i sent and got the sunSun to see how the election went my love to mrs and mr OconorO'Connor and mrs and mr Borroughs Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [13, 20, or 27? March 1868]
